content.title: Phlegmasia Alba Dolens and Phlegmasia Cerulea Dolens
content.definition: Severe forms of deep vein thrombosis characterized by massive iliofemoral venous occlusion. Phlegmasia alba dolens (PAD): 'painful white leg' with edema but preserved arterial flow. Phlegmasia cerulea dolens (PCD): 'painful blue leg' with venous gangrene risk from compromised arterial inflow.

key_concepts.description: Massive iliofemoral DVT causing severe leg edema, pain, and pallor (white appearance from edema); arterial inflow preserved; precursor to phlegmasia cerulea dolens
Progression of phlegmasia alba; near-total venous outflow obstruction → venous hypertension so severe it impairs arterial inflow → cyanosis (blue appearance), impending venous gangrene
End-stage of phlegmasia cerulea dolens; arterial inflow compromised by massive venous hypertension; irreversible tissue necrosis; high amputation and mortality rates
Complete iliofemoral and calf vein thrombosis → no venous outflow → massive edema (compartment syndrome equivalent) → venous pressure exceeds capillary perfusion → arterial compromise → gangrene
Severe leg pain, massive edema, pallor (white appearance), cool limb; pulses may be diminished from edema but still present
Severe pain, massive edema, cyanosis (blue mottled appearance), absent or very weak pulses, petechiae, bullae, impending gangrene
Often occurs with hypercoagulable states; malignancy (especially pancreatic, lung); recent surgery; pregnancy; May-Thurner syndrome predisposition
Urgent anticoagulation; leg elevation; consider catheter-directed thrombolysis or mechanical thrombectomy for iliofemoral disease
Vascular emergency; immediate anticoagulation; catheter-directed thrombolysis preferred; surgical thrombectomy if no response; fasciotomy if compartment syndrome; amputation if irreversible
Phlegmasia cerulea dolens has high mortality (20-40%) and amputation rate (12-25%); alba has better prognosis if treated promptly before progression

learning_objectives: Distinguish phlegmasia alba (white) from cerulea (blue) dolens
Understand the progression: DVT → alba → cerulea → venous gangrene
Recognize phlegmasia cerulea as a vascular emergency
Know that limb is at risk from venous, not arterial, pathology
clinical_pearls: Alba = painful WHITE leg (edema, pallor, preserved arterial flow)
Cerulea = painful BLUE leg (cyanosis, impaired arterial flow, gangrene risk)
Cerulea is venous cause of limb-threatening ischemia - unusual!
Think of malignancy (especially pancreatic cancer) as underlying cause
Thrombolysis/thrombectomy urgent for cerulea to prevent gangrene
20-40% mortality, 12-25% amputation rate in phlegmasia cerulea
common_mistakes: Treating as simple DVT (needs aggressive intervention)
Delaying intervention hoping for anticoagulation response
Confusing with acute arterial occlusion (this is venous pathology)
